body:
Note that we've re-opened the releases branches for development so `tp33` is now on 3.8.0-SNAPSHOT. 

> I did not get time to look at those tests yet. I will take them up in the coming weeks.

ok - i'm sorry, but it's not clear from your response if you intend to make those changes on this PR or a future one. i think i'm ok to merge this as-is because it's not really introducing a new problem, so much as shedding light on one. i just wouldn't want to forget that we have those leaks that need review.

upon further thought, i think it would be nice if this PR had some Upgrade Documentation for providers to call their attention to what's been done here.  Maybe there should even be some details in the [Provider documentation](http://tinkerpop.apache.org/docs/current/dev/provider/#_implementing_gremlin_core)? Including some docs of this nature would be a nice addition, but I can probably write something up on merge if you like. Just let me know.
VOTE +1
Done.

1. Added provider documentation, please feel free to modify it as you deem fit.
2. Started a JIRA to track the task of fixing the remaining JIRA's. https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TINKERPOP-2238
3. Rebased with tp33.

This PR is now ready for review.

1. I have added the tests as discussed in the JIRA associated with this PR.
2. There is an issue with Netty being tracked in https://github.com/netty/netty/pull/9226 which might cause some weird behaviour while closing the client. I am on it right now and will fix it separately from this PR.

@github5775 First of all, thanks for reporting this problem and putting in the effort to improve the driver!
I would just suggest that you [create an issue](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TINKERPOP/) first in the future as that allows us to discuss about the problem and different ways to handle it before you create a PR.

I'm actually not sure whether we want to expose the connection status to users. What are they supposed to do with that information?
I think it makes more sense for us to decide whether we want to fail fast in this case or attempt to re-connect to the server (and then fail if that doesn't work).

The second approach seems to make most sense as it allows us to handle the problem without the user even noticing it and if we can't reconnect, it becomes easier for users to handle that as they just have to catch an exception.
A closed connection should be an exceptional case and therefore we shouldn't require users to check before each request whether the connection is closed in my opinion.

@jorgebay What's your take on this?

Looks like there might be a problem somewhere - travis is complaining of:

```text
[INFO] -------------------------------------------------------------
[ERROR] COMPILATION ERROR : 
[INFO] -------------------------------------------------------------
[ERROR] /home/travis/build/apache/tinkerpop/gremlin-test/src/main/java/org/apache/tinkerpop/gremlin/process/traversal/step/filter/WhereTest.java:[276,146] method convertToVertex in class org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.AbstractGremlinTest cannot be applied to given types;
  required: org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.structure.Graph,java.lang.String
  found: java.lang.String
  reason: actual and formal argument lists differ in length
```

The Provider docs look good by the way...thanks

I agree with @FlorianHockmann, I wouldn't want users to have to check the connection status before submitting a traversal.

We can continue discussing in a ticket if necessary. In any case, thanks @github5775 for your patch and I look forward for future contributions.

Strangely, I am not able to repro the latest test failure on my local setup (mvn clean install -DskipIntegrationTests=false on tinkergraph is successful). I am looking into this. Will update the PR when I have fixed it.
i just restarted the job - i wonder if there is something non-deterministic in there somehow....
This is ready for review.
Disabled leak check on failing tests. This is ready for review now.

A bit surprised we didn't see a test failure somewhere as a result of this change. travis doesn't apparently run those test. Did you happen to run:

`mvn clean install -DskipTests && mvn verify -pl gremlin-server -DskipIntegrationTests=false`

does that pass? 

I think i'll add that test variation to the travis builds.
I haven't run it because I was relying on the travis build actually. But running it now. Will comment later with the outcome
@spmallette all tests passed
VOTE +1
VOTE +1

All tests pass with `docker/build.sh -t -n -i`

VOTE +1

I just looked into this and I'm actually not sure I really understand the problem you are trying to solve here.
You are using `Connection.IsOpen` to check if the pool has a connection that is considered _open_.
You described the problem like this:

> When a consumer of the Gremlin.Net client calls to execute a Gremlin query, i.e. "SubmitAsync," and the connection is not open, there will be a costly timeout error. I have experienced 30 to 90 second timeouts.

but I don't understand yet how this can occur and how this PR can improve the situation, considering that [the `ConnectionPool` already checks](https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/blob/d3ad5dee67435189e7bedd1a7ee9580d4cd629f7/gremlin-dotnet/src/Gremlin.Net/Driver/ConnectionPool.cs#L127) the `Connection.IsOpen` property for all connections before it uses one and then throws an exception if no connection is open.

If no connection is open, you shouldn't experience timeouts, you should be getting an exception. Is that really not the case?
VOTE +1
VOTE +1
VOTE +1

Are there concerns with https://github.com/netty/netty/pull/9226 ? Is that a problem we introduce as a new exposed risk as a result of this PR or is it something that can happen now with how things work in `tp34`? 

I think the code changes seems fine from the best I can tell by just scanning through. I had a few nits around the "deprecated" bits of code. If you could just do a quick pass through and add the appropriate javadoc in the form we use, that would be great. For future reference, here's some additional information in our dev docs on the topic:

http://tinkerpop.apache.org/docs/current/dev/developer/#_deprecation

No need to include the `@see` link everywhere to the JIRA i don't think....perhaps a strategically placed one somewhere would suffice. 

I would really like to see the documentation changes to consider it all a "finished" PR though. Specifically I think I'd like to see:

1. User Documentation - delete the deprecated settings from the docs and modify configuration/best practices sections as needed to reflect how the driver works now.
2. User Upgrade Documentation - something to call attention to this change and explains what was done and why (much of that is here in your PR description so you could probably copy/paste a bit) as well as what users need to do on upgrade to be sure everything works well.
3. Provider Upgrade Documentation - document any things that might possibly break as a result of this change (you mentioned "providers have provided a custom channelizer" for example).

Starting the process of testing manually now. Assuming I don't run into any problems there, when you push the documentation changes, I think this PR will be basically good to go. Thanks.

> i see that HasOpenConnection checks both IsOpen and _connectionState, but ConnectionPool only checks IsOpen.

`HasOpenConnection` checks `Connection.IsOpen` which looks like this:

```c#
public bool IsOpen => _webSocketConnection.IsOpen && Volatile.Read(ref _connectionState) != Closed;
```

so it already uses both.

> i will try to reproduce this to be able to tell you the exact line where this manifests. then i will try to sign up for the jira group and add it as an issue.

Great! 

We don't necessarily need the exact line for a JIRA issue (although that would of course help). So, as soon as you have something that helps us to understand the issue, you can create an issue in JIRA so we can start discussing about how to resolve it.

I think we can then close the PR now?
Yes, they both call that IsOpen, so I will look deeper.  Yes, we can close the PR.

Thanks for the fix. I think that this change makes sense. Could you please clean up the commit history a bit though? You have two commits on this pull request when one would be enough (just rebase/squash).  When you rebase, could you please target the `tp33` branch as I think the problem goes all the way back to the 3.3.x line of code. Once that's done I think that we can get it merged.

Also, if you want to make this pull request fully complete, please add a [CHANGELOG entry](https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/blob/7a18d92b018050324417f56fe3481a6797539df1/CHANGELOG.asciidoc#tinkerpop-338-release-date-not-officially-released-yet) - i can handle it myself though when i merge if you like.

VOTE +1 (note to other reviewers who might come along, i will probably merge this small change via CTR)

> Are there concerns with netty/netty#9226 ? Is that a problem we introduce as a new exposed risk as a result of this PR or is it something that can happen now with how things work in tp34?

The impact of the problem is that the connections to the server might not close gracefully and it would be up to the server to determine that they are idle/broken and close them. I think this problem exists in the current implementation as well and hence, should not be a regression. Though, I would suggest that we should pick up this bug fix from Netty (they have a very fast release cycle) before our next release.

> I would really like to see the documentation changes to consider it all a "finished" PR though. 

I have added some documentation. Please check and let me know your thoughts about it.
old pr refer:  https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/pull/1127

> I have added some documentation. Please check and let me know your thoughts about it.

lgtm

your first pull request looks fine. thanks for taking the time to offer spelling/grammar fixes. the only thing you might want to consider for future PRs of this type is the version. we currently maintain 3.3.x on the `tp33` branch, 3.4.x on the `tp34` branch and 3.5.0 (unreleased) on `master`, so given that you've submitted this PR against `master` the change will technically only go to 3.5.0 which has no release date as of yet. It would be nice if you could target future PRs to the earliest branch to show the problem, then when it's merged it will apply to all the branches ahead of it when we merge the change forward. For this PR I will cherry-pick your change to `tp33` as the problem does exist there:

http://tinkerpop.apache.org/docs/3.3.7/reference/#vertexprogram

and then merge it forward to the other branches. Hope that makes sense...feel free to ask questions if you need clarification.

Changes:
1. Removed excessive logging for a genuine case (when a channel serving requests gets disconnected)
2. I had to fork the FixedChannelPool from Netty (TinkerpopFixedChannelPool) until the Netty PR mentioned above is resolved and TinkerPop starts consuming that version. That fixes the issue with the event executor terminated exceptions you mentioned above. I hope that is ok!

Some of these changes are caused due to Netty version upgrade e.g. channelInactive being called on channel close (which is the correct behaviour). Hopefully, the tests should pass now. If they don't I will work on it and let you know when this PR is ready to review.

This was all generally fine. Not sure about the hyphen on the cypher-to-gremlin thing, so you might see that revert at some point but its merged for now. Note that the web site needs to be republished for these changes to appear. My intention is to wait for a more critical set of changes before doing that. Thanks!

The `tp33` branch is fine - note that `tp32` and earlier branches are basically EOL at this point (discussion for [3.2.x EOL](https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/e682b89b93b72f647388577798372ac957dd6ed3625851f323350b5e@%3Cdev.tinkerpop.apache.org%3E) is going on now technically on the dev list) so no need to aim any more work at them.  Anyway, merged this to all [three release branches](https://tinkerpop.apache.org/docs/current/dev/developer/#branches). Thanks again

https://api.travis-ci.org/v3/job/545093810/log.txt

I'm returning to my thinking that we should consider making this a change on the `master` branch for 3.5.0. If we did that we could:

1. skip "deprecation" take a full breaking change and just delete the dead code
1. wait for the netty release with your PR allowing both them and us to confirm stability
1. stage up for some bigger changes to better abstract aspects of the `Client` API (which i want to start on soon and will just create conflicts with this PR which will be annoying to resolve), etc. 
1. start a feature branch from `master` and merge this PR into it so that we could collaborate better and evolve this big body of change together. 

I know that you really wanted to see this on the 3.4.x line, but perhaps you might reconsider that position. Thoughts?

Can't think of a reasonable way to sort out the "copied" files I alluded to above, at least not without re-working how the Maven build works. At this stage, it's probably better that we simply have this docker capability than re-working the maven stuff. Also, I don't see much change happening to these files anymore so perhaps it's not a big deal (certainly not as big as the amount of copy/paste we had before the maven refactoring to unify testing across GLVs. Added some comments to remind us that changes to the test configuration in gremlin-server will need to be replicated to docker.

The latest travis build errors are due to some container issue with errors such as `incompatible event loop type: io.netty.channel.epoll.EpollEventLoop`. It was working earlier and all tests pass on my OSX laptop. This issue seems very specific to Epoll on the container. It might be a result of either Netty upgrade or some change in the container that runs the test itself and will take some time to debug!

Nevertheless, I agree with your suggestion to move this into 3.5.x. However, I am still concerned about the prevailing bugs in the 3.4.x and 3.3.x client. Perhaps we can work on small localized changes in the existing client to plug the holes while we work on the 3.5.x story? I will file some JIRAs with the tests that repro the bugs and we can tackle them together.

Nice that we didn't have to change the API on `GraphTraversal` to support this.  A couple issues:

1. I think some upgrade docs would be nice in this case, because this is a neat feature to call attention to.
2. I think the test you added is fine, but the problem is that it doesn't validate operations for GLVs. I assume GLVs will work, but it would be nice to see a test added that would validate that.

Regarding your first question, I guess "v[3]" in the previous example isn't clear. As for your second question "TinkerPop" and "the stack" are one in the same. I've pushed some changes to help clarify.

Glad you are on board with moving this larger change off to 3.5.0. i guess we need to figure out how to move this work to a feature branch. perhaps i just create a "driver-3.5.0" branch from "master" and then you target this PR at that? From there I can just merge i those changes and that branch would be the home for stabilizing the big driver change for 3.5.0?

> Perhaps we can work on small localized changes in the existing client to plug the holes while we work on the 3.5.x story? I will file some JIRAs with the tests that repro the bugs and we can tackle them together.

+1

+1 The change looks good and should fix this issue.

This is my hypothesis for what is happening:
On CorruptedFrameException, Netty sends a CloseFrame to gracefully close the WebSocket connection asynchronously and throws the exception [1]. The exception is handled by the handler and when we check for Connection.isDead(), it is actually alive at that time waiting for the response to the CloseWebSocket frame. This same connection gets allocated to the next request and at some time it receives the response to the CloseWS frame and the handler attached to the response closes the channel, in turn, closing the second request.

In the new client we plan to write for 3.5, we should handle this case in a better manner. Please note that Netty's behaviour wrt to CorruptedFrameException has changed as of 4.1.37. We need to factor that change as well in future versions [2]

[1] https://github.com/netty/netty/blob/netty-4.0.56.Final/codec-http/src/main/java/io/netty/handler/codec/http/websocketx/WebSocket08FrameDecoder.java#L446
[2] https://github.com/netty/netty/commit/7fc718db3cd52e82901dfc3fe8b437ae1ff75d4e

+1 - I am aware of the logic and the code change look good.

Thanks for completing this!
VOTE +1
VOTE +1
I've lost track of what's happening with this PR - can this be closed given the fix on #1114
Well I would claim that this is the more elegant solution compared to #1114.

Basically, what Connection does today is manually keep track of a send-queue, starting a send-loop on the first enqueue, exiting it when it drains. We saw that the code required to make it thread-safe with lock-freedom is quite involved. The main point of that approach, however, is just to linearize sends while not blocking queued-up send requests. So what this PR does is protect the critical region by a SemaphoreSlim which allows async waits (no blocking!), and we can get rid of the explicit queue, counters etc.
Does that merge commit need to be in this branch? I think you just needed to rebase on `master` right?
VOTE +1
VOTE +1
VOTE +1

@spmallette Ready to pull into a new branch!

Where shall we discuss ideas about the new client? Do we have a gitter/IRC for TinkerPop?

I've cherry-pick'd your commits and squashed them to the new `driver-35` branch based on `master`. we can do major refactoring there, so please target such changes at that branch.  I will periodically rebase it on master to keep it up to date. Obviously, we'll need to coordinate a bit when that happens.

> Where shall we discuss ideas about the new client?

The expectation for Apache projects is that all project communication should happen on the dev list, so feel free to send emails there to get major themes of discussion started. If we get into some minutiae or need some quick back and forth discussion we can just probably talk on IM directly and then report our discussion back to the dev list (which might just mean updating a JIRA or commenting on a PR as we have been doing). 

closing this PR now. thanks

I think this was a good change, however now that I look at it I think it was partially implemented the way that it was to avoid a breaking change in Gremlin Server along 3.3.x and 3.4.x.  Is there a way to approach this with an eye for deprecation? 

Here's some ideas I'm just throwing out there to consider.......they aren't fully thought through and just meant to foster some discussion.

Maybe `OpProcessor` could deprecate `ThrowingConsumer<Context> select(final Context ctx) ` and introduce the `ResponseHandlerContext` version of that method which would have a default implementation of returning `null` (or maybe a static do-nothing marker `ThrowingConsumer` instance). Then in `OpSelectorHandler` we would just try that method first and if it returns `null` we just use the old deprecated method. I guess that would mean that `OpExecutorHandler` will need some further adjustment to handle both types of Pairs coming at it....maybe that's not so good.

What about `Context`? Do we need both a `ResponseHandlerContext` and a `Context`? Now that I'm looking at it, I kinda wonder if we couldn't just merge the functionality of `ResponseHandlerContext` into `Context` and then deprecate `ResponseHandlerContext` and related methods? I did speak with @dimas-b for a bit and he didn't see any problem with merging the two - his reasoning for introducing `ResponseHandlerContext` was mostly to not alter what `Context` was basically doing as a simple holder for Gremlin Server objects as `ResponseHandlerContext` was bringing in actions like `writeAndFlush()`.  Maybe this is an avenue to explore?

Other ideas?

Nice pom work and great to see upgrade docs. 

> Migration to 3.5 will require some efforts.

good to know - thanks. 

> Looks like #1042 could be merged after this

I will rebase that PR and see what happens. It still needs some work to get it to the finish line before merge but at least it might build properly as a feature branch.

Thanks for this contribution - I think neo4j users will be excited to see this.

Any future PRs related to TINKERPOP-2133 should be based on and directed to that branch. I'm happy to handle this another way if it is presented here....thanks.

I offered a few immediate thoughts on your work and I think I will have more as I think it through further. Please let me know if you have questions/comments so far.

I am very very sorry for inadvertently close the PR。
The previous pr and suggestion here: https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/pull/1157
Issue could be found here：https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TINKERPOP-2252?filter=-2

some solutions here： 
1. Please note that we don't have a particular code style in TinkerPop but we do try to not use wildcard imports and we try to final variables where it makes sense to do so.
**_It is Intellij's default config and i have already fix it_**

2. some class level javadoc here would be good. Please provide a reference to GroovyTranslator and explain the difference between this one and that one. A javadoc link from GroovyTranslator to this class would be nice too.
**_I have add some javadoc before ParameterizedGroovyTranslator and explain the relation with GroovyTranslator, and i think  link from GroovyTranslator is unnecessary and it could make this relations looks  Complex_**

3. I think that you need to implement this slightly differently. I don't think you want a new parameterizedTranslate(Bytecode) method. I think you just want:
public ParameterizedGroovyResult translate(Bytecode)
**_Yes，I'm worried about changing to other files at the beginning. I have modified on your advice。_**

4. it would be nice if this could all be implemented as a simple TypeTranslator because then we wouldn't need this special Translator implementation. Still thinking about how this might all "just work" so I could perhaps suggest more changes after these, but for now, I don't think that the constructor for ParameterizedGroovyTranslator should have a construction that take a simple TypeTranslator:
because for it to extract parameters it needs a special kind of TypeTranslator (i.e. one that captures parameters like this one). So, you might need a new ParameterizedTypeTranslator interface to accomplish that. I wish you didn't though. Overall this needs a bit more thought to get t right.
**_I think the constructor for ParameterizedGroovyTranslator have a construction that take a simple TypeTranslator may be sometimes valuable，the class  will be more extensible and provide an interface for user to customize personal Translator.ParameterizedScriptTranslator  just like ParameterizedSillyClassTranslator exhibited in ParameterizedGroovyTranslatorTest.java.
It will surely make code expanded and complicated somehow，I will accept your opinion with open heart. Hoping for your more constructive comments_**

Subject: Re: [apache/tinkerpop] Tinkerpop 2252 Support Parameterized Groovy Script Transformation (#1158)



@spmallette commented on this pull request.
 
 
In gremlin-groovy/src/main/java/org/apache/tinkerpop/gremlin/groovy/jsr223/ParameterizedGroovyTranslator.java:
 > +    } + +    @Override +    public String toString() { +        return StringFactory.translatorString(this); +    } + +    @Override +    public String getTraversalSource() { +        return this.traversalSource; +    } + +    /** +     * Performs standard type translation for the TinkerPop types to Parameterized Groovy. +     */ +    public static class DefaultTypeTranslator implements TypeTranslator {  
It bothers me a bit that the TypeTranslator is being used for more than just converting types which was its original intent so that providers/users could plugin their own conversions for custom types. If we implement things the way they are now, they not only have to write two separate TypeTranslators (if they want to support both forms of translation) but they also have to reason about Parameters. I'm not sure what the solution is there, but I think that's the next thing that's concerning me about this change that I don't have a good answer for yet.
 
—

VOTE +1 

The logic and the code change looks good.

I've had some more time to think about this. I'm having trouble envisioning the complete impact to this change so please forgive me for suggesting changes that might seem like I'm taking this design in circles.

That said, I think that everything works more nicely if the `ScriptTranslator` interface changed and simply became:

```java
public interface ScriptTranslator extends Translator<Script, String>
```

where `Script` is what you currently have named `ParameterizedScript `. Going forward, `Script` can have parameters or not so:

```java
public Optional<Map<String,Object>> getParameters()
```

Now, `ParameterizedGroovyTranslator` can go away, and we can just use `GroovyTranslator` which will return a `Script` with or without parameters based on the `TypeTranslator` given to it. I think `DefaultTypeTranslator` should simply be configurable by way of the constructor to extract parameters or not. 

I think that these changes should allow you to get rid of the `ThreadLocal` in `Parameters` hopefully (another thing that was bothering me). It allows existing extensions of `DefaultTypeTranslator` to take advantage of `Parameters` in a way that doesn't make them have to reason about that (i.e. they can just add their custom types for conversion and choose whether they opt to parameterize them or not). I think it also unifies the API more nicely for downstream usage. All of this comes at the cost of a breaking change to our APIs, but I think that's acceptable.

I'm not sure if that's all the changes that need to be done for this to be "ready", but I think I'd need to see them in place before I could say more. At least I'm seeing the bigger picture of how this fits more clearly now. Please let me know what you think.

Also, a couple of administrative notes:

1. Please prefer `git rebase` when bringing in new changes from master to your branch (i see a merge commit on this PR - please remove that when you get a chance - thanks)
2. Don't worry about travis too much - I tend to keep an eye on it and will let you know if there is a test that won't pass because of a change you made. Please consider using docker to validate your builds in addition to local maven builds as docker will run all tests across all Gremlin Language Variants - `docker/build.sh -t -i` will give you extraordinary confidence that your changes are "good".

Thanks for your patience with this pull request.

I change the code to avoid calling processAllStarts when there are still traversers in barrier instead of limiting the processAllStarts only be called only.

VOTE +1

I just wanted to mention that we intend to release 3.3.8/3.4.3 around the beginning of august and that we will enter into our normal one week period of code freeze on July 26th at close of business. This message is not meant to rush you; it only serves to inform you of the pending release in case you wanted to get this change merged in time for that. Thanks
Wow, sorry I missed this patch to review, thanks for taking care of this!

I have merged the `ResponseHandlerContext` into `Context`. There is no change in the interfaces and hence, code is backward compatible. This change also brings this closer to how Netty works with the context, where the pipeline operations like write and flush are done via the context object.

Let me know if this addresses your concerns.

Wow - that looks a lot better. Great job!  Did you have to completely delete `ResponseHandlerContext` though? It seems like there was a way to deprecate it while maintaining the method signatures that were using it thus avoiding a breaking change. Was there a problem that forced you into complete removal?

Sorry, I didn't understand your comment the last time about making changes with an eye on deprecation.

I will make the change but I don't understand the motivation here. Why do you consider removing the `ResponseHandlerContext` a breaking change? The class has simply been refactored (or its functionality decomposed into other classes) while maintaining the same business logic as before. 

As part of Tinkerpop development, do we not delete anything without first marking it as deprecated, even if it is an internal class/function?

We try not to create compile time problems during patch releases to make it as easy as possible for both providers and users to upgrade. I understand your use of "internal" there in that it's sort of a in-the-weeds sort of class but `ResponseHandlerContext` more strictly speaking it's not really an internal class in the sense that it was scoped public and then also part of methods that were public and therefore possibly utilized in some fashion (likely by providers and not so much end users). Obviously, if the class were scoped in a fashion that didn't allow folks to use it directly then there wouldn't be a problem with just removing it.

That's not to say that we don't make exceptions or never have breaking compile time changes (pretty rare I think which I like to take some pride in), but personally I prefer them more as a last resort as I imagine that few providers want to fuss very much with their implementations on older TinkerPop release lines (like `tp33`). Just trying to keep the wheels greased for upgrade as much as possible. 

Is this a case for allowing the breaking change through? It's not a clear "yes" in my mind, since I *think* I see a pretty simple deprecation path. Of course, the fix for a provider who upgraded would be fast/easy plus they get a good bug fix for making the change, so if we let it go as-is, it wouldn't be the end of the world - some upgrade docs would probably be required for providers so that they were aware of the change and it would be all good. 

So, sorry to make you shift one more time, but if you can take the deprecation approach without breaking compile time on upgrade, then let's do that. If you're sick of working on this ticket, I can finish it up for you. Just let me know.

For the future, prefer deprecation with no breaks in compilation/behavior on older branches. If there is no such path then we probably should discuss the approach to see if the community can live with the breaking change.
